Topics.Strand: Qualification structure and options

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Course elements (required studies)
Sub_topics.description: Understand the required elements that make up AQA GCSE History (8145): students study one period study, one thematic study, one wider world depth study, and one British depth study that includes the historic environment.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Paper 1 options: Period study choices
Sub_topics.description: Know the four possible Paper 1 Section A (Period study) options and that one must be selected at entry: AA America, 1840–1895: Expansion and consolidation; AB Germany, 1890–1945: Democracy and dictatorship; AC Russia, 1894–1945: Tsardom and communism; AD America, 1920–1973: Opportunity and inequality.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Paper 1 options: Wider world depth study choices
Sub_topics.description: Know the five possible Paper 1 Section B (Wider world depth study) options and that one must be selected at entry: BA Conflict and tension: The First World War, 1894–1918; BB Conflict and tension: The inter-war years, 1918–1939; BC Conflict and tension between East and West, 1945–1972; BD Conflict and tension in Asia, 1950–1975; BE Conflict and tension in the Gulf and Afghanistan, 1990–2009.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Paper 2 options: Thematic study choices
Sub_topics.description: Know the three possible Paper 2 Section A (Thematic study) options and that one must be selected at entry: AA Britain: Health and the people: c1000 to the present day; AB Britain: Power and the people: c1170 to the present day; AC Britain: Migration, empires and the people: c790 to the present day.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Paper 2 options: British depth study choices (with historic environment)
Sub_topics.description: Know the four possible Paper 2 Section B (British depth study including the historic environment) options and that one must be selected at entry: BA Norman England, c1066–c1100; BB Medieval England: the reign of Edward I, 1272–1307; BC Elizabethan England, c1568–1603; BD Restoration England, 1660–1685.

Topics.Strand: Course requirements and scope

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Required eras, timescales, and geographical contexts
Sub_topics.description: Know the required scope of study: history from three eras (Medieval 500–1500; Early Modern 1450–1750; Modern 1700–present day), on three timescales (short depth study; medium period study of at least 50 years; long thematic study), and in three geographical contexts (locality via historic environment; British; European and/or wider world).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: British history minimum proportion
Sub_topics.description: Understand the requirement that British history must form a minimum of 40% of assessed content across the full course.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Thematic study (long sweep) requirement
Sub_topics.description: Understand the purpose and requirement of the thematic study: change and continuity across a long sweep of history; must cover all three specified eras (Medieval, Early Modern, Modern).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Period study (medium timespan) requirement
Sub_topics.description: Understand the purpose and requirement of the period study: a substantial and coherent medium time span of at least 50 years; requires understanding of unfolding narrative of substantial developments and issues; may be from any specified era.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Depth studies requirement (British + wider world)
Sub_topics.description: Understand the requirement for two depth studies: one British depth study and one European/wider world depth study; depth studies focus on a substantial and coherent short time span; develop understanding of complexities and interplay within a society/situation; depth studies must be taken from different eras.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Historic environment study requirement
Sub_topics.description: Understand the purpose of the historic environment: study a particular site in historical context to understand relationship between place and historical events/developments; no requirement to visit; may be linked to other course content or stand alone (in this specification it is embedded in the British depth study option).

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Understanding the modern world (Period studies)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Geography and Manifest Destiny
Sub_topics.description: Understand the geography of North America and how it shaped attitudes and expansion: attitudes to the Great American Desert and the belief in ‘Manifest Destiny’ as an idea driving westward expansion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early settlement west: motives, groups, challenges
Sub_topics.description: Explain why early settlers went west and the challenges faced, including case studies and groups: Brigham Young and the Mormons; pioneer migrant farmers and the journey west; miners (motivations, experiences, and difficulties).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Plains Indians and early government policy
Sub_topics.description: Understand Plains Indians’ way of life; early US Government policy towards Plains Indians including the Permanent Indian Frontier; explain how relationships changed between settlers/government and Plains Indians over time.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Fort Laramie (1851) and Indian Wars 1862–1867
Sub_topics.description: Analyse increasing conflict on the Plains: Fort Laramie Treaty (1851); failure of the policy of concentration; Indian Wars (1862–1867) including reasons and consequences; Sand Creek Massacre; Fetterman’s Trap.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Background to the American Civil War and impacts
Sub_topics.description: Explain the background causes of the American Civil War: differences between North and South; slavery; westward expansion and free states; abolitionism; breakdown of the Missouri Compromise; John Brown; roles of Abraham Lincoln and Jefferson Davis; analyse the social and economic impact of the Civil War on civilian populations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mountain Meadows Massacre and Mormon relations
Sub_topics.description: Understand conflict and accommodation involving the Mormons: the Mountain Meadow(s) Massacre and its aftermath; explain how US authorities and wider society came to terms with the Mormons.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Reconstruction and federal vs state power
Sub_topics.description: Assess the aftermath of the Civil War: 13th Amendment; Civil Rights Act; Reconstruction in the South (1866–1877); role of carpetbaggers; explain changing balance of Federal and State powers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Homesteaders, railroads and farming on the Plains
Sub_topics.description: Explain continued settlement of the West after the Civil War: Homesteaders and reasons for going west; government actions and laws; land and railroads; farming problems and attempted solutions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: ‘Indian problem’ after 1865: reservations, Dawes Act, Wounded Knee
Sub_topics.description: Analyse how the US tried to resolve the ‘Indian problem’ after 1865: small reservations policy; attitudes to Native Americans; Battle of the Little Big Horn; Dawes Act; Battle of Wounded Knee; closing of the frontier and its impact on Native Americans.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Understanding the modern world (Period studies)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kaiser Wilhelm II: governing difficulties and society
Sub_topics.description: Explain difficulties of ruling Germany under Kaiser Wilhelm II: growth of parliamentary government; influence of Prussian militarism; industrialisation; social reform and growth of socialism; domestic importance of the Navy Laws.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact of the First World War on Germany
Sub_topics.description: Analyse the impact of the First World War: war weariness and economic problems; defeat and end of the monarchy; post-war problems including reparations, occupation of the Ruhr, and hyperinflation.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Weimar democracy and unrest, 1919–1923
Sub_topics.description: Understand political change and unrest in Weimar Germany 1919–1923 including Spartacists, Kapp Putsch and Munich Putsch; explain threats to democracy and government responses.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stresemann era recovery, 1924–1929
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate the extent of recovery during the Stresemann era (1924–1929): economic developments (new currency; Dawes Plan; Young Plan); impact of international agreements on recovery; and features/impact of Weimar culture.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Depression and Nazi rise, 1928–1932
Sub_topics.description: Explain how the Depression affected Germany and contributed to growth in support for Nazis and other extremist parties (1928–1932), including the role of the SA and Hitler’s appeal.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Failure of Weimar and Hitler appointed Chancellor
Sub_topics.description: Analyse why Weimar democracy failed: election results; roles of Papen and Hindenburg; reasons Hitler was appointed Chancellor.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Establishing the Nazi dictatorship, 1933–1934
Sub_topics.description: Explain steps in establishing Hitler’s dictatorship: Reichstag Fire; Enabling Act; elimination of political opposition; control of trade unions; Röhm and the Night of the Long Knives; Hitler becomes Führer.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nazi economic policy and war economy effects
Sub_topics.description: Assess economic changes under the Nazis: benefits and drawbacks; employment; public works programmes; rearmament; self-sufficiency; and impact of war on the economy and German people including bombing, rationing, labour shortages and refugees.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nazi social policy: women, youth, churches, race and the Holocaust
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for Nazi social policies, how they were implemented, and their impacts: on women; young people/youth groups; education; control of churches and religion; Aryan ideas and racial policy; persecution and the Final Solution.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Control, propaganda, terror and opposition
Sub_topics.description: Analyse how the Nazis maintained control: Goebbels; propaganda and censorship; Nazi culture; repression and the police state including roles of Himmler, the SS and Gestapo; opposition and resistance including White Rose group, Swing Youth, Edelweiss Pirates and the July 1944 bomb plot.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Understanding the modern world (Period studies)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Russian economy and society before 1917
Sub_topics.description: Understand Russia’s economy and society under the Tsars: industrialisation and its effects; living and working conditions in cities and villages (urban and rural experiences).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nicholas II’s autocracy and opposition, 1894–1914
Sub_topics.description: Explain Nicholas II’s autocracy and the court; growth of revolutionary opposition; the 1905 Revolution and October Manifesto; evaluate attempts to reform Russia up to 1914 including Dumas and political stalemate; Stolypin’s policies (land reform, industry, and use of oppression).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: First World War and collapse of Tsardom
Sub_topics.description: Analyse the First World War’s impact on Tsarist government: military defeats; social and economic effects on cities and countryside; unpopularity of the Romanovs including role of Rasputin; the Tsar’s abdication.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Provisional Government and Bolshevik takeover
Sub_topics.description: Explain the Provisional Government’s failures to deal with Russia’s social, economic and military problems; roles of Lenin and Trotsky; growth of Bolshevik organisation; the October/November Revolution.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Lenin’s dictatorship: ending WWI, Cheka, Red Army, Civil War
Sub_topics.description: Understand the impact of Lenin’s dictatorship: end of the First World War; role and methods of the Cheka; role of the Red Army; causes, nature and consequences of the Civil War; reasons for Bolshevik success; use of propaganda.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: War Communism, Kronstadt, NEP and Lenin/Trotsky’s achievements
Sub_topics.description: Explain social and economic developments under Lenin: War Communism; causes and significance of the Kronstadt Rising; the New Economic Policy (NEP); assess achievements of Lenin and Trotsky.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stalin’s rise and dictatorship: Party control, terror and propaganda
Sub_topics.description: Analyse Stalin as dictator: power struggle to succeed Lenin; Communist Party control over government; Terror and Purges including the army, secret police, labour camps; censorship; cult of personality; propaganda.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Stalin’s modernisation: collectivisation and Five Year Plans
Sub_topics.description: Explain Stalin’s modernisation policies: collectivisation and the Five Year Plans; assess social and economic consequences for kulaks, city dwellers, women, professional and industrial workers; evaluate the extent of modernisation achieved.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: USSR and the Second World War to 1945
Sub_topics.description: Assess the impact of the Second World War (Great Patriotic War) on the USSR up to 1945: Stalin’s wartime leadership and resulting political, economic and social problems.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Understanding the modern world (Period studies)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: The 1920s Boom: consumerism, production, policy and inequality
Sub_topics.description: Explain the causes and characteristics of the 1920s ‘Boom’: benefits; advertising and consumer society; hire purchase; mass production (Ford and the motor industry); inequalities of wealth; Republican government policies; stock market boom.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 1920s social and cultural change: entertainment and women
Sub_topics.description: Understand social and cultural developments in the 1920s: entertainment (cinema, jazz); position of women in society including flappers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Divisions and tension: Prohibition, crime, racism, immigration, Red Scare
Sub_topics.description: Analyse why American society was divided in the 1920s: organised crime; Prohibition and its impact; causes of racial tension; experiences of immigrants and impact of immigration; Ku Klux Klan; Red Scare and the significance of the Sacco and Vanzetti case.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Depression and Hoover vs Roosevelt
Sub_topics.description: Understand American society during the Depression: unemployment and impact on groups (farmers, businessmen); Hoover’s responses and unpopularity; reasons for Roosevelt’s election as president.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: New Deal effectiveness and opposition
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of the New Deal for different groups: successes and limitations; opposition from the Supreme Court, Republicans and Radical politicians; Roosevelt’s contribution as president; relationship with popular culture.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Second World War impact on US economy and society
Sub_topics.description: Explain how the Second World War affected the USA: economic recovery; Lend Lease; exports; social developments including experiences of African-Americans and women.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Post-war prosperity, culture and McCarthyism
Sub_topics.description: Analyse post-war American society and economy: consumerism and causes of prosperity; the ‘American Dream’; McCarthyism; popular culture including Rock and Roll and television.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Civil Rights in the 1950s–1960s
Sub_topics.description: Understand racial tension and developments in Civil Rights campaigns: segregation laws; Martin Luther King and peaceful protests; Malcolm X and the Black Power Movement; Civil Rights Acts of 1964 and 1968.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Kennedy/Johnson Great Society and feminism (1960s–early 1970s)
Sub_topics.description: Explain the ‘Great Society’ social policies of Presidents Kennedy and Johnson relating to poverty, education and health; analyse development and impact of feminist movements in the 1960s and early 1970s including equal pay; National Organisation for Women (NOW); Roe v Wade (1973); Supreme Court ruling on equal rights (1972); and opposition to the Equal Rights Amendment.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Understanding the modern world (Wider world depth studies)
Topics.Topic_name: BA Conflict and tension: The First World War, 1894–1918

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Alliance system and international crises
Sub_topics.description: Explain the Alliance System and how it increased tension: Triple Alliance; Franco-Russian Alliance; relations between the Entente powers; crises in Morocco (1905, 1911) and the Balkans (1908–1909) and their effects on international relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Anglo-German rivalry and rearmament
Sub_topics.description: Analyse Anglo-German rivalry: Britain’s challenges to Splendid Isolation; Kaiser Wilhelm II’s aims (Weltpolitik); colonial tensions; European rearmament including the Anglo-German naval race.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Outbreak of war in 1914
Sub_topics.description: Explain outbreak of war: Slav nationalism; Serbia and Austria-Hungary; assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand and consequences; July Crisis; Schlieffen Plan and Belgium; reasons for escalation and outbreak of hostilities.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Schlieffen Plan failure and stalemate
Sub_topics.description: Understand the Schlieffen Plan: reasons for the plan; reasons it failed including the Battle of Marne; explain how this contributed to stalemate.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Western Front: trench warfare, tactics, technology and key battles
Sub_topics.description: Analyse the Western Front: military tactics and technology including trench warfare and attrition; key battles (Verdun, Somme, Passchendaele) including reasons, events and significance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: The wider war: other fronts and war at sea
Sub_topics.description: Explain the wider war beyond the Western Front: Gallipoli and reasons for failure; war at sea including Jutland, U-Boat campaign and convoys (events and significance).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Russia withdraws and USA enters the war
Sub_topics.description: Explain changes in Allied forces: consequences of Bolshevik Revolution and Russia’s withdrawal for German strategy; reasons for and impact of US entry into the war.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 1918 offensives and Germany’s defeat
Sub_topics.description: Analyse 1918 military developments leading to German defeat: evolution of tactics and technology; Ludendorff and the Spring Offensive; Allied advance during the Hundred Days.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Germany surrenders and responsibility for defeat
Sub_topics.description: Explain Germany’s surrender: impact of the blockade; abdication of the Kaiser; armistice; contributions of Haig and Foch to Germany’s defeat.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Understanding the modern world (Wider world depth studies)
Topics.Topic_name: BB Conflict and tension: The inter-war years, 1918–1939

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Armistice and aims of the peacemakers
Sub_topics.description: Understand the armistice context and aims of key peacemakers: Wilson and the Fourteen Points; Clemenceau; Lloyd George; evaluate the extent to which they achieved their aims.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Treaty of Versailles terms
Sub_topics.description: Know and explain the Treaty of Versailles settlement: concept of diktat; territorial changes; military restrictions; war guilt clause; reparations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact and evaluation of the wider settlement
Sub_topics.description: Analyse impact of the treaty and wider settlement: reactions of the Allies; German objections; strengths and weaknesses of the settlement including problems faced by new states.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: League of Nations: structure, powers and agencies
Sub_topics.description: Understand the League of Nations: formation and covenant; organisation; membership and changes; powers; work of agencies; strengths/limitations implied by structure and membership.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: League successes and failures in the 1920s
Sub_topics.description: Evaluate the League’s contribution to peace in the 1920s through case studies: Aaland Islands; Upper Silesia; Vilna; Corfu; Bulgaria (successes, failures, and reasons).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Diplomacy outside the League
Sub_topics.description: Understand attempts at diplomacy outside the League: Locarno Treaties and the Kellogg–Briand Pact (aims and significance).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Collapse of the League in the 1930s
Sub_topics.description: Explain why the League collapsed: effects of the Depression; Manchurian and Abyssinian crises and consequences; failure to avert war in 1939.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hitler’s aims and early tensions, 1933–1935
Sub_topics.description: Analyse development of tension: Hitler’s aims and Allied reactions; Dollfuss Affair; Saar; German rearmament including conscription; Stresa Front; Anglo-German Naval Agreement.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Appeasement and escalation to 1939
Sub_topics.description: Explain escalation of tension: remilitarisation of the Rhineland; Mussolini, the Axis, and the Anti-Comintern Pact; Anschluss; reasons for and against appeasement; Sudeten Crisis and Munich; ending of appeasement.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Outbreak of war and responsibility
Sub_topics.description: Explain outbreak of the Second World War: occupation of Czechoslovakia; role of USSR and Nazi–Soviet Pact; invasion of Poland and outbreak of war (Sept 1939); assess responsibility including roles of key individuals Hitler, Stalin and Chamberlain.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Understanding the modern world (Wider world depth studies)
Topics.Topic_name: BC Conflict and tension between East and West, 1945–1972

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Post-war conferences and division of Germany
Sub_topics.description: Understand the end of WWII and origins of Cold War tension: Yalta and Potsdam Conferences; division of Germany; contrasting attitudes/ideologies of USA and USSR including aims of Stalin, Churchill, Roosevelt, Attlee and Truman; effect of the atom bomb on post-war superpower relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Iron Curtain: Soviet expansion and US response
Sub_topics.description: Explain Soviet expansion in Eastern Europe and evolution of East–West rivalry; US policies including Truman Doctrine and Marshall Plan (purpose and Stalin’s reaction); Cominform; Comecon; Yugoslavia; Berlin Blockade and Airlift.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cold War in Asia and superpower relations
Sub_topics.description: Analyse significance of Asia for superpower relations: USSR support for Mao Zedong and Communist revolution in China; military campaigns waged by North Korea against the UN; and by the Vietcong against France and the USA (as international context affecting superpower rivalry).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Arms race, alliances and space race
Sub_topics.description: Explain military rivalries: arms race; membership and purposes of NATO and the Warsaw Pact; space race including Sputnik, ICBMs, Polaris, Gagarin and Apollo (and their significance for Cold War competition).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: The Thaw: Hungary and U2 Crisis
Sub_topics.description: Understand the ‘Thaw’: Hungary (protest movement and Nagy’s reforms), Soviet fears and response, and effects on the Cold War; U2 Crisis and its effects on Paris Peace Summit and peace process.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Berlin Wall and Kennedy’s response
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for construction of the Berlin Wall and evaluate Kennedy’s response and significance for Cold War relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Cuban Missile Crisis and key individuals
Sub_topics.description: Analyse tensions over Cuba: Castro’s revolution; Bay of Pigs; missile crisis including roles of Castro, Khrushchev and Kennedy; US fears and reaction to missiles; dangers and results of the crisis.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prague Spring and Brezhnev Doctrine
Sub_topics.description: Explain Czechoslovakia 1968: Dubček and the Prague Spring reforms; USSR response; effects on East–West relations including Warsaw Pact action; Brezhnev Doctrine.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Détente and SALT I
Sub_topics.description: Understand easing of tension: sources of tension including Soviet human rights record; reasons for Détente; reasons for SALT I; role of key individuals Brezhnev and Nixon.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Understanding the modern world (Wider world depth studies)
Topics.Topic_name: BD Conflict and tension in Asia, 1950–1975

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Causes of the Korean War
Sub_topics.description: Explain causes of the Korean War: nationalism in Korea; US relations with China; division of Korea; roles of Kim Il Sung and Syngman Rhee; reasons North invaded South in June 1950; US and UN responses; significance of USSR absence from the UN.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Course of the Korean War
Sub_topics.description: Understand development of the Korean War: UN campaign in South and North Korea; Inchon landings and recapture of South Korea; UN advance into North Korea; China’s reaction and intervention (Oct 1950); sacking of MacArthur.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: End and impact of the Korean War
Sub_topics.description: Explain end of the Korean War: stalemate around the 38th Parallel; peace talks and armistice; impact for Korea, the UN and Sino-American relations.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: End of French rule and origins of Vietnam conflict
Sub_topics.description: Explain end of French colonial rule: Dien Bien Phu and consequences; Geneva Agreement (1954); civil war in South Vietnam; opposition to Diem; Vietcong aims, support, leadership, guerrilla tactics; role of Ho Chi Minh.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early US involvement: Domino Theory and Strategic Hamlets
Sub_topics.description: Understand growth of US involvement: Domino Theory; intervention under Eisenhower and Kennedy; Strategic Hamlets programme (aims, implementation, and impact).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Johnson’s War and turning points
Sub_topics.description: Analyse escalation under Johnson: Gulf of Tonkin; US response to Vietcong tactics; mass bombing; demands for peace and growing student protests in USA; My Lai and its public impact; Search and Destroy tactics and impact; Tet Offensive and consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Nixon’s War: Vietnamisation and widening conflict
Sub_topics.description: Explain Nixon’s War: Vietnamisation; chemical warfare; bombing campaigns 1970–1972; relations with China; widening war into Laos and Cambodia.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Opposition to the war and the role of media
Sub_topics.description: Understand opposition to war: Kent State University; importance of media/TV in influencing public opinion; context and impact of the Watergate affair on perceptions of government.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: End of the war and consequences by 1975
Sub_topics.description: Explain end of the Vietnam War: Paris Peace talks; role of Kissinger; US withdrawal; fall of Saigon; price of conflict; problems of Vietnam in 1975.

Topics.Strand: Paper 1: Understanding the modern world (Wider world depth studies)
Topics.Topic_name: BE Conflict and tension in the Gulf and Afghanistan, 1990–2009

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Regional instability and background tensions in the Gulf
Sub_topics.description: Understand sources of tension in the Gulf: consequences of the Iran–Iraq war; Western and Russian interests in/attitudes towards Iran and Iraq including the threat to oil supplies; contribution of the Israeli–Palestinian conflict to Gulf tension and to motives for global terrorism.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: The Gulf War (1990): invasion of Kuwait and response
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for Iraqi invasion of Kuwait (1990); reactions and roles of Bush and Thatcher; UN campaign against Saddam Hussein; consequences of the war including US influence in the region and Arab reactions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Al-Qaeda and 11 September attacks
Sub_topics.description: Understand Al-Qaeda: its aims, and the role of Osama bin Laden; the 11 September (9/11) attacks and their significance for international relations and subsequent conflicts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Afghanistan under the Taliban and internal challenges
Sub_topics.description: Explain why Afghanistan was seen as a rogue state; the Taliban regime; Western and Muslim attitudes towards Taliban policies; problems faced by ethnic groups; resurgence of the Taliban.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: 2001 intervention: Bush, Blair and aftermath in Afghanistan
Sub_topics.description: Analyse Bush’s war against terror and intervention in Afghanistan: Bush’s aims; Blair’s support; 2001 US/UK operation; overthrow and collapse of Taliban regime; UN peace conference; problems faced by Karzai’s government.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Saddam’s Iraq: repression, divisions and international attitudes
Sub_topics.description: Understand Saddam Hussein’s regime: treatment of Kurds and Shia Muslims; debate about Iraq’s links to Al-Qaeda and rogue state reputation; religious divisions within Iraq; international attitudes and the role of the UN.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Invasion of Iraq (2003): WMD/IAEA and the campaign
Sub_topics.description: Explain the invasion of Iraq 2003: IAEA inspectors and WMD issue; military campaign; Western interests including oil; opposition within Iraq and internationally; downfall of Saddam Hussein.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Impact of Iraq War: insurgency, politics and global terrorism
Sub_topics.description: Analyse the impact of the Iraq War: effects on Iraqi people and globally; Insurgency; elections and transfer of powers to National Assembly; global anti-US and anti-UK terrorism; 2007 US troop surge; stability of Iraq by end of Bush’s presidency.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Shaping the nation (Thematic studies)
Topics.Topic_name: AA Britain: Health and the people: c1000 to the present day

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Thematic framework and factors for change in medicine
Sub_topics.description: Understand the thematic enquiry for medicine and public health in Britain c1000–present: track change/continuity; analyse causes, scale, nature and consequences of short/long-term developments and their impact on British society; reference wider world developments only in terms of their effects on Britain. Apply the specified factors to explanations and judgements: war; superstition and religion; chance; government; communication; science and technology; role of the individual in encouraging or inhibiting change. Be able to evaluate varying rates of change, progress, significance, and different types of causes/consequences (short/long-term; intended/unintended).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval medicine: beliefs, practitioners and treatments
Sub_topics.description: Explain approaches to medieval medicine: natural and supernatural explanations; Hippocratic and Galenic ideas (e.g., humours) and methods/treatments; role of the medieval doctor; training; beliefs about causes of illness.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medical progress in the Middle Ages: Christianity, Islam and surgery
Sub_topics.description: Assess medical progress in the Middle Ages: contribution of Christianity to treatment and medical progress including hospitals; nature and importance of Islamic medicine and surgery; medieval surgery ideas and techniques.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Public health in the Middle Ages and the Black Death
Sub_topics.description: Understand medieval public health in towns and monasteries; explain the Black Death in Britain including contemporary beliefs about causes, treatments and prevention methods.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Renaissance impact: anatomy, physiology and surgical challenge
Sub_topics.description: Explain how the Renaissance challenged medical authority in Britain: advances in anatomy, physiology and surgery; work of Vesalius and Paré; William Harvey’s work; opposition to change and reasons for resistance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early modern disease treatment and medical profession changes
Sub_topics.description: Understand dealing with disease in the early modern period: traditional and new treatments; quackery; methods of treating disease; plague; growth of hospitals; changes to training and status of surgeons and physicians; work of John Hunter.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Prevention: inoculation and Jenner’s vaccination
Sub_topics.description: Explain development of preventative medicine: inoculation; Edward Jenner and vaccination; opposition to vaccination and reasons for resistance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Germ Theory and bacteriology: Pasteur, Koch, Ehrlich
Sub_topics.description: Explain the development of Germ Theory and its impact on treatment of disease in Britain: importance of Pasteur; Robert Koch and microbe hunting; Pasteur and vaccination; Paul Ehrlich and ‘magic bullets’; links to everyday medical treatments and remedies.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Revolution in surgery: anaesthetics, antiseptics and asepsis
Sub_topics.description: Analyse surgical revolution: development and impact of anaesthetics (including Simpson and chloroform); antiseptics (including Lister and carbolic acid); changes in surgical procedures; development of aseptic surgery.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Public health reform in industrial Britain: cholera and Public Health Acts
Sub_topics.description: Explain public health problems in industrial Britain; cholera epidemics; role of public health reformers; local and national government involvement including the 1848 and 1875 Public Health Acts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern disease treatment: pharmaceuticals and penicillin
Sub_topics.description: Understand modern treatment of disease: development of the pharmaceutical industry; penicillin (discovery by Fleming and subsequent development); emergence of new diseases and treatments; antibiotic resistance; alternative treatments.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: War/technology and modern surgery
Sub_topics.description: Explain impact of war and technology on surgery: plastic surgery; blood transfusions; X-rays; transplant surgery; modern surgical methods including lasers, radiation therapy and keyhole surgery.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Modern public health and the NHS
Sub_topics.description: Analyse modern public health developments: importance of Booth, Rowntree and the Boer War; Liberal social reforms; impact of two world wars on public health, poverty and housing; Beveridge Report and Welfare State; creation and development of the National Health Service (NHS); costs, choices and healthcare issues in the 21st century.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Shaping the nation (Thematic studies)
Topics.Topic_name: BB Britain: Power and the people: c1170 to the present day

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Thematic framework: power, protest and political development
Sub_topics.description: Understand the thematic enquiry into the relationship between citizen and state in Britain c1170–present: causes, scale, nature and consequences of protest and responses; journey from feudalism/serfdom to democracy/equality; how the state responds to challenges and the impact; rights and responsibilities of the citizen. Consider wider world influences on Britain. Apply factors: war; religion; chance; government; communication; economy; ideas (equality, democracy, representation); role of individuals. Evaluate rates of change, progress, significance, and types of causes/consequences (short/long-term; intended/unintended).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Magna Carta and constraints on kingship
Sub_topics.description: Explain barons’ dissatisfaction with King John and its resolution; terms of Magna Carta; assess its short- and long-term impact on kingship, rights and governance.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Origins of Parliament: Henry III, Simon de Montfort and 1265
Sub_topics.description: Understand issues between Henry III and barons; role of Simon de Montfort; Provisions of Oxford; Parliament of 1265; evaluate short- and long-term impact on development of Parliament.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Peasants’ Revolt: causes, events and impact
Sub_topics.description: Analyse social, economic and political causes of the Peasants’ Revolt; actions of rebels and government; evaluate impact of the Revolt on royal authority and society.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Pilgrimage of Grace and Tudor authority
Sub_topics.description: Explain social, economic, religious and political causes of the Pilgrimage of Grace; implications for royal authority; Henry VIII’s reaction; impact of the uprising.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: English Revolution and the Commonwealth
Sub_topics.description: Analyse causes of the English Revolution; role of the New Model Army and political radicalism during the Civil War era; assess short- and long-term impact including significance of trial and execution of Charles I, Oliver Cromwell and the Commonwealth.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: American Revolution: representation and authority
Sub_topics.description: Explain causes of the American Revolution including relationship between government and people; assess impact and significance of the American Revolution for ideas of representation and rights.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Franchise reform: Great Reform Act and Chartism
Sub_topics.description: Understand extension of the franchise: radical protest; causes and impact of the Great Reform Act, including further reform; Chartism—causes, actions and impact.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Campaigning groups and social reform movements
Sub_topics.description: Explain protest and change through campaigning groups: methods and impact of Anti-Slavery movement; Anti-Corn Law League; factory reformers; social reformers (and how they influenced state policy).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Trade unionism and workers’ movements in the 19th century
Sub_topics.description: Analyse development of trade unionism and its impact: Grand National Consolidation Trades Union (GNCTU); Tolpuddle Martyrs; New Model Unions; ‘new unionism’ including match girls’ strike and dockers’ strikes.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Women’s suffrage and gender equality
Sub_topics.description: Explain the campaign for women’s suffrage: reasons, methods and responses; role of individuals including the Pankhursts; reasons for extension of the franchise and its impact; progress towards equality in the second half of the 20th century.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Workers’ rights in the 20th century: General Strike and later reforms
Sub_topics.description: Understand workers’ rights developments: General Strike (1926) actions, reactions and impact; trade union reform in the late 20th century.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Minority rights since 1945 and Brixton Riots
Sub_topics.description: Analyse development of a multi-racial society since WWII; discrimination, protest and reform; Brixton Riots and their impact including the Scarman Report.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Shaping the nation (Thematic studies)
Topics.Topic_name: AC Britain: Migration, empires and the people: c790 to the present day

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Thematic framework: migration, conquest, empire and identity
Sub_topics.description: Understand how British identity has been shaped by interaction with the wider world c790–present: invasions and conquests; Britain’s relationship with Europe and wider world; ebb/flow of peoples into and out of Britain; motives and achievements; acquisition and retreat from Empire and its impact/legacy for ruled and ruling. Apply factors: war; religion; government; economic resources; science and technology; ideas (imperialism, social Darwinism, civilisation); role of individuals. Evaluate rates of change, progress, significance, and short/long-term and intended/unintended consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Vikings and Anglo-Saxons: Danelaw and North Sea Empire
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for Viking invasions; creation of the Danelaw; role of Alfred and Wessex; King Cnut, Emma of Normandy and the North Sea Empire (and impacts on settlement, governance and identity).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Normans, Angevin Empire and England–France–Ireland relations
Sub_topics.description: Understand a Norman kingdom and ‘Angevin’ Empire: relationship between England and France; Henry II; invasion of Ireland; losses under King John (and implications for power and identity).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Hundred Years’ War and English identity
Sub_topics.description: Analyse the birth/development of English identity through the Hundred Years’ War and assess its impact on England’s future development.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Caribbean sugar and the slave trade
Sub_topics.description: Explain looking west via Caribbean: piracy and plunder; development of the slave trade including John Hawkins; settlements in Barbados and the West Indies; economic and social impact of the slave trade on Britain.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: North American colonisation and loss of American colonies
Sub_topics.description: Explain British colonisation in North America: causes and consequences; Raleigh; Jamestown; contact and relations with indigenous peoples; commodities; Pilgrim Fathers; indentured servants; War of Independence and loss of American colonies.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Early modern migration to/from Britain: Huguenots, clearances, Ulster
Sub_topics.description: Understand migrants to and from Britain: Huguenot migration; Highland clearances; Ulster plantations (motives, experiences, and impacts).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: India: East India Company and British control
Sub_topics.description: Analyse expansion in India: causes and impact of British control; East India Company; Robert Clive; Warren Hastings; Indian Rebellion (1857); social, political, cultural and economic impact of empire on Britain and India.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Africa: Scramble, Rhodes and Boer War
Sub_topics.description: Explain expansion in Africa: causes and impact of British involvement; trade and missionary activity; South Africa; Egypt; Scramble for Africa; Cecil Rhodes; Boer War (1899–1902); imperial propaganda.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Industrial/imperial era migration flows
Sub_topics.description: Understand migrants to, from and within Britain and the Empire: Irish migration to Britain; Jewish migration to Britain; transportation; migration to and within the Empire including migration of Asians to Africa; migration from rural to urban settings.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: End of Empire: wars, Suez, and independence movements
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for and process of retreat from empire: impact of First and Second World Wars; impact of Suez; nationalism and independence in India and Africa including roles of Gandhi, Nkrumah and Kenyatta.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Legacy of Empire and post-war migration
Sub_topics.description: Analyse legacy of empire: Windrush and Caribbean migrants; Claudia Jones’ work in the UK; migration from Asia and Africa including role of Amin in Uganda; the Commonwealth; Falklands War (and how these shaped identity and relations).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Britain and Europe: interaction and migration
Sub_topics.description: Understand Britain’s relationship with Europe and its impact: effects of WWII; economic, social and cultural interaction; end of Cold War and membership of the European Union; European and non-European migration (patterns and impacts).

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Shaping the nation (British depth studies + historic environment)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Succession crisis and causes of conquest (1066)
Sub_topics.description: Explain causes of the Norman Conquest: death of Edward the Confessor; main claimants and their claims (and why the succession crisis led to invasion).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Battles of Stamford Bridge and Hastings; tactics and castles
Sub_topics.description: Understand military aspects of conquest: Battle of Stamford Bridge; Battle of Hastings; compare Anglo-Saxon and Norman tactics; explain military innovations including cavalry and castles.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Norman control: Harrying, revolts and William’s leadership
Sub_topics.description: Analyse establishing and maintaining control: Harrying of the North; revolts 1067–1075; William I’s leadership and government; William II and his inheritance (continuity/change in rule).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Feudalism, landholding, government and justice
Sub_topics.description: Explain feudalism and Norman governance: roles/rights/responsibilities; landholding and lordship; land distribution and patronage; compare Anglo-Saxon and Norman government systems; changes in aristocracy and society; military service; justice and legal system including ordeals and ‘murdrum’; inheritance; purpose and significance of the Domesday Book.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Economic and social life under the Normans; Forest Law
Sub_topics.description: Understand economic and social changes and consequences: features of Anglo-Saxon vs Norman life including towns, villages, buildings, work, food, roles and seasonal life; Forest Law and its effects.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Church reforms: Lanfranc, organisation and Church–state relations
Sub_topics.description: Explain the Church in Norman England: features of Anglo-Saxon Church pre-1066; Archbishop Lanfranc and reforms including building churches/cathedrals; Church organisation and courts; Church–state relations; William II and the Church; wealth of the Church; relations with the Papacy; Investiture Controversy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Monasticism: reforms, learning and language
Sub_topics.description: Understand Norman monastic reforms: building abbeys and monasteries; monastic life; learning; schools and education; Latin usage and the vernacular (cultural impacts).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Historic environment (Norman England): site study requirements
Sub_topics.description: Know the historic environment requirement for this depth study: historic environment is 10% of overall course (~12 hours of 120 GLH); AQA specifies a particular site to be examined in depth, changed annually and published three years in advance; no requirement to visit. Be able to answer an essay-style question applying second order concepts (change/continuity/causation/consequence) to the specified site and its relationship with wider Norman England developments. Understand how to analyse the site through: location; function; structure; people connected (designer/originator/occupants); design; how design reflects culture/values/fashions; links to events/developments from the depth study. Understand representativeness of the site and how features changed from earlier periods and during the period; make links to associated aspects such as cathedrals/abbeys/castles/towns/settlements and how trade/revolts/battles were shaped by the environment.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Shaping the nation (British depth studies + historic environment)
Topics.Topic_name: BB Medieval England - the reign of Edward I, 1272–1307

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Henry III’s legacy and Edward I’s kingship
Sub_topics.description: Explain Henry III’s legacy: relationship between Edward and Henry III; problems faced on Edward I’s accession; relations with the nobility; Edward I’s character as a king.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Government, rights and justice reforms under Edward I
Sub_topics.description: Understand development of government, rights and justice: Hundred Rolls; role of Robert Burnell; Statutes of Westminster; Statutes of Mortmain; ‘Quo Warranto’ inquiries; parliaments and the ‘Model Parliament’ (1295).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Economy, trade and towns: wool, taxation and Jews (1290)
Sub_topics.description: Explain trade, towns and villages: agriculture and wool trade; royal finance and taxation including wool tax; Statute of Merchants; role of Italian bankers; re-coinage; expulsion of the Jews in 1290 (causes and consequences).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Education and learning: Church, universities and scholars
Sub_topics.description: Understand education and learning in medieval England: role of the medieval Church and universities; contributions/ideas associated with Roger Bacon and Duns Scotus.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Legal system and crime: courts, punishments and statutes
Sub_topics.description: Explain development of the legal system: laws and courts; trials; crimes; criminals and punishments; Statutes of Gloucester (1278) and Winchester (1285) and their impacts.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Medieval warfare: tactics and technology
Sub_topics.description: Understand medieval warfare tactics and technology: siege warfare; battlefield use of cavalry and infantry; weapons and armour (and how these shaped campaigns).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Wales: conquest, colonisation and castles
Sub_topics.description: Explain invasion and colonisation of Wales: Edward’s Welsh Wars (1277 and 1282–1283); Statute of Rhuddlan; castle building; costs and consequences.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Scotland: succession, Wallace and war of independence
Sub_topics.description: Analyse relations with Scotland: ‘Great Cause’ and Scottish succession; Balliol and Bruce; Scottish campaigns; William Wallace; First War of Scottish Independence from 1297 to Edward I’s death; evaluate Edward I’s reputation as ‘Hammer of the Scots’.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Historic environment (Edward I): site study requirements
Sub_topics.description: Know the historic environment requirement for this depth study: historic environment is 10% (~12 hours of 120 GLH); AQA specifies an annually changing site linked to Edward I content and published three years in advance; no visit required. Be able to answer a question applying change/continuity/causation/consequence to the specified site in its wider medieval context. Analyse site via location; function; structure; associated people; design and cultural values; and links to events/developments (trade, towns/villages, churches, manor houses/castles, revolts/battles/wars). Understand representativeness and how features changed from earlier periods and within the period studied.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Shaping the nation (British depth studies + historic environment)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Elizabeth I’s character, court and ministers
Sub_topics.description: Understand Elizabeth I and her court: Elizabeth’s background and character; court life including patronage; roles and importance of key ministers.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Female rule: Parliament, marriage, succession and authority
Sub_topics.description: Explain difficulties of a female ruler: relations with Parliament; the problem of marriage and succession; assess strength of Elizabeth’s authority by end of reign including Essex’s rebellion (1601).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Golden Age culture: living standards, gentry and theatre
Sub_topics.description: Understand ‘Golden Age’ claims and reality: living standards and fashions; growing prosperity and rise of the gentry; Elizabethan theatre and achievements; attitudes to the theatre.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Poverty and Poor Laws
Sub_topics.description: Explain reasons for increase in poverty; contemporary attitudes and responses; reasons for government action and evaluate seriousness of the problem (policy responses).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: English sailors, exploration and trade
Sub_topics.description: Understand role of English sailors: Hawkins and Drake; circumnavigation 1577–1580; voyages and trade; role of Raleigh (motives, methods, outcomes).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Religious settlement and threats: rebellion, plots, Puritans
Sub_topics.description: Analyse religious matters: English Catholicism and Protestantism; Northern Rebellion; Elizabeth’s excommunication; missionaries; Catholic plots and threats to settlement; nature/ideas of Puritans and Puritanism; Elizabeth’s and government responses and policies towards religion.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Mary Queen of Scots: challenge and execution
Sub_topics.description: Explain the challenge of Mary Queen of Scots: her background; treatment by Elizabeth and Parliament; plots; execution and its impact on domestic/foreign policy.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Spain and the Armada
Sub_topics.description: Understand conflict with Spain: reasons; events; naval warfare tactics and technology; defeat of the Spanish Armada (causes and significance).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Historic environment (Elizabethan): site study requirements
Sub_topics.description: Know the historic environment requirement for this depth study: historic environment is 10% (~12 hours of 120 GLH); AQA specifies an annually changing site linked to Elizabethan England, published three years in advance; no visit required. Answer a question applying change/continuity/causation/consequence to the specified site and wider Elizabethan developments. Analyse site via location; function; structure; associated people; design and cultural values/fashions; links to events/developments (Tudor manor houses/gardens, theatres, villages/towns/cities, voyages/trade, revolts, battles). Understand representativeness and how features changed from earlier periods and within the period studied.

Topics.Strand: Paper 2: Shaping the nation (British depth studies + historic environment)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Restoration settlement: Crown, Parliament and politics
Sub_topics.description: Explain Crown and Parliament issues: legacy of Civil War and Commonwealth; restoration of monarchy; succession issue; relations/issues with Parliament including finance and religion; Cabal and emergence of ‘party politics’; Charles II’s rule without Parliament from 1681.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Catholic question: plots and Exclusion Crisis
Sub_topics.description: Analyse the Catholic question: Titus Oates and the Popish Plot; Rye House Plot; Exclusion Bill (1679); role and significance of James, Duke of York.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Charles II’s court culture and character
Sub_topics.description: Understand Charles II’s character; court life; fashions; and the political/cultural role of the court.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Great Plague (1665) and Fire of London (1666)
Sub_topics.description: Explain crises of Restoration London: Great Plague of 1665 (causes, contemporary views, measures to combat, records, results); Fire of London 1666 (causes, contemporary views, results and reconstruction).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Restoration culture: theatre, women, coffee houses, science and architecture
Sub_topics.description: Understand Restoration culture: Restoration comedy/theatres/playwrights; role and status of women; coffee houses; Charles II’s patronage of arts and sciences including the Royal Society; Samuel Pepys; architecture and design including Christopher Wren.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Empire and land: trading companies and colonies
Sub_topics.description: Explain land/imperial developments: powers of the East India Company; acquisition/significance of Bombay; Hudson Bay; Tangier; Captain Henry Morgan and Jamaica (and how these linked to trade/war).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Trade policy: mercantilism, Navigation Acts and slave trade
Sub_topics.description: Analyse Restoration trade: mercantilism; Navigation Acts and their impact; slave trade (role in economy and empire).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: War at sea: Dutch Wars and foreign relations
Sub_topics.description: Understand English sea power and naval warfare (tactics and technology); conflict with the Dutch including Second and Third Dutch Wars; relations with Spain and France (causes and consequences).

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Historic environment (Restoration): site study requirements
Sub_topics.description: Know the historic environment requirement for this depth study: historic environment is 10% (~12 hours of 120 GLH); annually changing AQA-specified site linked to Restoration England, published three years in advance; no visit required. Answer an extended question applying change/continuity/causation/consequence to the specified site and wider Restoration developments. Analyse site via location; function; structure; associated people; design and cultural values/fashions; links to events/developments (stately homes/gardens, theatres, villages/towns/cities; trade; plots; revolts; battles). Understand representativeness and how features changed from earlier periods and within the period studied.

Topics.Strand: Assessment objectives and exam skills

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: AO1: Knowledge and understanding
Sub_topics.description: AO1 requirements: demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the key features and characteristics of the period studied, including accurate and relevant detail used to support explanations and judgements across all studied options.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: AO2: Second-order concepts (analysis/explanation)
Sub_topics.description: AO2 requirements: explain and analyse historical events and periods using second-order historical concepts: continuity, change, cause, consequence, significance, similarity and difference; apply these concepts to construct explanations and reach substantiated conclusions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: AO3: Sources (analysis, evaluation, use)
Sub_topics.description: AO3 requirements: analyse, evaluate and use contemporary sources to make substantiated judgements in context; includes using content, provenance and contextual knowledge to assess usefulness/utility and reach supported conclusions.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: AO4: Interpretations (analysis, evaluation, judgement)
Sub_topics.description: AO4 requirements: analyse, evaluate and make substantiated judgements about interpretations (including understanding how and why interpretations may differ) in the context of historical events studied; does not require historiography beyond evaluating given interpretations.

Topics.Strand: Assessment structure (Paper 1)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Section A question types (Period study)
Sub_topics.description: Know Paper 1 Section A structure and skills: six compulsory questions (40 marks) including three AO4 interpretation questions (how interpretations differ; why interpretations differ; how convincing interpretations are), one AO1 ‘Describe…’ question on two key features/characteristics, one AO2 change question supported by AO1 knowledge, and one extended judgement essay (AO1+AO2) focused on causation/consequence/change/continuity across identified aspects.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Section B question types (Wider world depth study)
Sub_topics.description: Know Paper 1 Section B structure and skills: four compulsory questions (40 marks) per depth study: (1) AO3 source analysis (one source); (2) AO3 usefulness/utility of sources (two sources; written/visual); (3) AO1+AO2 ‘Write an account…’ narrative focusing on cause/consequence; (4) extended judgement essay (AO1+AO2) using second-order concepts; plus SPaG marks available on the final essay question.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Paper 1 marks, time and weighting
Sub_topics.description: Know Paper 1 assessment details: written exam 2 hours; 84 marks including 4 SPaG; accounts for 50% of GCSE; Section A 40 marks, Section B 40 marks, plus 4 SPaG.

Topics.Strand: Assessment structure (Paper 2)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Section A question types (Thematic study)
Sub_topics.description: Know Paper 2 Section A structure and skills: four compulsory questions (40 marks): (1) AO3 usefulness of a source using content/provenance/context; (2) AO1+AO2 significance (importance at the time and over time); (3) AO1+AO2 similarity/difference comparison; (4) extended judgement essay (AO1+AO2) evaluating one stated factor against others (eg war, religion, chance, government, communication, science/technology, role of individual) across all four parts of the thematic content; SPaG marks available on the essay.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Section B question types (British depth study + historic environment)
Sub_topics.description: Know Paper 2 Section B structure and skills: four questions (40 marks): (1) AO4 evaluation of one interpretation (visual or written) using contextual knowledge; (2) AO1+AO2 explanation applying causation/change/continuity/consequence; (3) AO1+AO2 ‘Write an account…’ narrative applying cause/change/continuity/consequence; (4) AO1+AO2 extended essay linked to the specified historic environment site, focusing on relationship between site and wider events/developments and applying change/continuity/cause/consequence.

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: Paper 2 marks, time and weighting
Sub_topics.description: Know Paper 2 assessment details: written exam 2 hours; 84 marks including 4 SPaG; accounts for 50% of GCSE; Section A 40 marks, Section B 40 marks, plus 4 SPaG.

Topics.Strand: Assessment structure (SPaG)

Sub_topics.Sub_topic_name: SPaG performance descriptors
Sub_topics.description: Know how SPaG marks are awarded in extended responses: High performance (4 marks) = consistent spelling/punctuation accuracy; effective grammar control of meaning; wide range of specialist terms. Intermediate (2–3 marks) = considerable accuracy; general grammar control; good range of specialist terms. Threshold (1 mark) = reasonable accuracy; some control of meaning; limited specialist terms. 0 marks if nothing written, not related, or errors severely hinder meaning.
